document.docTitle: Promalactis voluta Wang & Liu 2020, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic study of the genus Promalactis Meyrick, 1908 (Lepidoptera Oecophoridae). VII. The cornigera species group, with descriptions of six new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic study of the genus Promalactis Meyrick, 1908 (Lepidoptera Oecophoridae). VII. The cornigera species group, with descriptions of six new species

Diagnosis. This new species can be distinguised by the costal margin with a yellowish grey spot before the distal 1/3. It is similar to
P. cornigera
Meyrick, 1918
in features of the male genitalia, but can be separated from the latter by the gnathos widened distally, the sacculus with a right angle curved before the apex, and the aedeagus with two small cornuti almost equal length. In
P. cornigera
, the gnathos is slightly narrowed apically, the sacculus is smoothly arched preapically, and the aedeagus has two cornuti greatly different in length.

Description. Adult ( Fig. 6 ). Wingspan 9.0‒ 11.5 mm . Head with vertex brown, frons grey, occiput dark brown. Labial palpus with second segment ochreous yellow on inner surface, dark ochreous yellow on outer surface; third segment black, basal 1/4 and apex white dorsally. Antenna black; scape white ventrally, with a longitudinal white line dorsally; pecten white; flagellum annulated with white. Thorax and tegula with basal 2/3 dark ochreous yellow, distal 1/3 ochreous yellow. Forewing ochreous yellow; costal area covered with dense grey and black scales along basal 2/3; costal margin with a yellowish grey spot before distal 1/3 and with ill-defind black spot before and beyond it; dorsum with black scales medially, with white streak from about basal 2/5 and distal 1/4 crossing fold, respectively, edged with a few black scales; tornal spot black, conspicuous; apical spot black, formed by a few black scales, sometimes with a white dot; cilia yellow. Hindwing and cilia grey.
Distribution. China ( Guangxi , Hainan , Sichuan , Taiwan , Zhejiang).
Etymology. The specific epithet of this new species is derived from the Latin volutus , referring to the distally coiled ductus bursae.
